docs.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON -- In the early 1950s, a coal miner's daughter from rural Kentucky named Louise McIntosh encountered the shadowy world of illegal abortion. A friend was pregnant, with no prospects for marriage, and Ms. McIntosh was keeper of a secret that, if spilled, could have led to family disgrace. The turmoil ended quietly in a doctor's office, and the friend went on to marry and have four children. Today, Louise McIntosh is RepresentativeLouise M. Slaughter, Democrat of New York. At 80, she is co-chairwoman of the Congressional Pro-Choice Caucus -- a member of what Nancy Keenan, president of Naral Pro-Choice America, calls ''the menopausal militia.''
docs.snippet: WASHINGTON -- In the early 1950s, a coal miner's daughter from rural Kentucky named Louise McIntosh encountered the shadowy world of illegal abortion. A friend was pregnant, with no prospects for marriage, and Ms. McIntosh was keeper of a secret...

docs.lead_paragraph: As the Senate begins debate this week on health care legislation, the question of whether to keep the bill's provision for a government-run health insurance plan, known as the public option, will be one of the most contentious. The Democrats still have not nailed down the 60 votes they need to pass the provision. Three conservative Democrats and one independent are threatening to scuttle the entire legislation if the public option, as now written, stays in.

headline.main: Does Public Care About Public Option?
headline.kicker: PRESCRIPTIONS MAKING SENSE OF THE HEALTH CARE DEBATE

docs.abstract: Democrats still do not have 60 votes they need in Senate to pass provision of health care overhaul calling for government-run insurance plan known as public option; surveys show majority of public supports public option, but not as strongly as other goals such as lowering costs; support for public option may not outweigh doubts about other parts of bills; support for public option varies with how question is asked; photo (M)
docs.snippet: As the Senate begins debate this week on health care legislation, the question of whether to keep the bill's provision for a government-run health insurance plan, known as the public option, will  be one of the most contentious.     The Democrats...

docs.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON -- In the early 1950s, a coal miner's daughter from rural Kentucky named Louise McIntosh encountered the shadowy world of illegal abortion. A friend was pregnant, with no prospects for marriage, and Ms. McIntosh was keeper of a secret that, if spilled, could have led to family disgrace. The turmoil ended quietly in a doctor's office, and the friend went on to marry and have four children. Today, Louise McIntosh is RepresentativeLouise M. Slaughter, Democrat of New York. At 80, she is co-chairwoman of the Congressional Pro-Choice Caucus -- a member of what Nancy Keenan, president of Naral Pro-Choice America, calls ''the menopausal militia.''
docs.abstract: Fight over federal funding for abortion is threatening to thwart health care bill; development has galvanized abortion rights movement and forced its leaders to raise questions about how to carry agenda forward in world where many women cannot recall time when abortion was illegal and do not share memories of polarizing battles that led to Roe v Wade; pressures relating to abortion seemed to have gone dormant until Rep Bart Stupak, supported by 64 Democrats, proposed amendment barring use of federal subsidies for insurance plans that cover abortions; issue presents conundrum for Rep Louise Slaughter and other women who share vivid recollections of pre-Roe world but who also favor health care bill; photo; drawing (M)
docs.snippet: For the post-Roe generation, abortion has been a personal choice and not a political cause. This worries pro-choice leaders in and out of Congress.

docs.lead_paragraph: In David Leonhardt's article (Nov. 8), readers learn about standards of care to which all medical providers should aspire. Short shrift was given, however, to the role of the patient. Consumeruse of online quality-rating sites is not an accurate measure of interest regarding health care choices. Patients and families must become the center of care if we are to reform our system. Massachusetts is starting down a path toward health care payment reform and consumer engagement in their care through programs like shared decision making and chronic-disease management. Our health care system can only improve if medical providers learn how to engage patients so that they can make treatment decisions together.

headline.main: Dr. James Will Make It Better

docs.abstract: Deborah W Wachenheim letter on Nov 8 article about Dr Brent James and Intermountain Healthcare
